Fields.DialogueText: Cześć! So, you must be the new Kapitan they've assigned to me, yes?
Yes, that's me. You must be Orzel! Pleased to meet you.

By all means, Kapitan, the pleasure's mine. I can assure you, I've been expecting your arrival for a while and it's great to meet you. Might have a bit of an odd question for you, if that's all right?
Ask away, Orzel.
When you wake up in the morning, what do you look at first: the sun, your clock, or your door?

Fields.MenuText: The sun, actually.
Well, I have a habit of checking my clock.
My... door? Did I hear that right?

Fields.DialogueText: So you sleep with your blinds open? Haha! I'll give you that, you're a wild one, Kapitan. I think you'll get along here just fine. It's all right, sunlight's lovely.
I figured! You look like a stand-up, punctual Kapitan! I just hope you aren't much of a dull-edge. Something's telling me you'll fit along here just fine.
Guhahaha! That's the -best- reaction I've ever gotten to that question! But, wait, do you actually look at your door when you wake up!? Hmhm... I like you already, Kapitan. Life's got many doors!
I hope I'll do well here, but... why the question, Orzel?
All in a day's riddle, Kapitan. I usually ask that question right away to people I know I'm going to be working with for a while. It helps me get to know what they're like!
It's one of the most unique I've been asked, I can tell you that.
That's only because you've never met somebody like me, Kapitan. I can tell just by looking at your eyes.
Eyes hold experience, words say a lot, but I intend to show up and not go off half-cocked. I'd be remiss if I did it to you, Orzel.
Hoho! Now -that- sounds promising... Well! Let me get you set up here, then. I'll have to introduce you to my crew!
I've heard you've got quite the bunch. I wouldn't expect less for a Belle who managed to get herself out of that deep of trouble.
Oh no, no, no, Kapitan. Make no mistake about it, that wasn't just me, that was my crew down to the core. I can do a lot of things myself, but it's what I can do with a crew that's really impressive.
Are they all as interesting as you?
Straight out of the docks with that question, huh, Kapitan? I think everybody here's got a story to tell. And, what stories—Oop! Did you feel that?
Sure did. I didn't think the Morgana would come this close to port.
Consider it a little welcome gift, Kapitan; my treat.
@BATTLE
All right, boys! We've got a new Kapitan on board! Wait... where are the others?
Sorry, Miss Orzel. They're all checking around the engine right now. Is this the Kapitan?
In the flesh!
Pleased to meet you.
Good to meet you, too, Kapitan. I'm Andrzej, I handle most of the technical stuff here in Orzel. I know all the ins-and-outs of her gears!

Fields.MenuText: She lets you poke around, does she?
You look like you know your stuff!
Why do you smell like... sulfurate?

Fields.DialogueText: Fuhahahahaha! That's rather crass, Kapitan. I'll have you know that I don't have just anyone poke around in here; after all, I do have my secrets. Regardless, Andrzej is careful and calculated.
Believe it or not, Andrzej procured some supplies that I didn't think were initially possible to come by in times like these. If there's anyone I trust with my maintenance, it's him.
I believe I'm to blame for that, Kapitan. I was trying some experimental ammunition the other day and I believe the scent of it still lingers about. Anrezej is trying to get rid of it.
Well met then, Andrzej. If Orzel speaks of you in such high regard, I have no doubts we'll get along just fine.
Why, Kapitan, thank you! I promise, I'll do my best. By the way, Miss Orzel. I believe I should be able to create more rust repellant if I could find some pneumonia...
Excuse me, pneumonia?
Caught you by surprise, Kapitan? Andrzej here was actually a student at Jagiellonian Univeristy.
Chemistry is my major, but my love is mechanics, and my heart belongs to Poland.
Would that happen to be in ascending or descending order?
We do not work in hierarchy here, Kapitan. Everyone works together.
All a part of the team, hm? I'll keep that in mind...
You can prove yourself as of this moment, Kapitan.
What do you mean by... (*BOOM*) O-Oof!
K-Kapitan! Hold on, I'll help you up!
That's what I mean. Here, take my hand. Let's get this underway.
Now -that's- my line. All right, everyone, let's take those Morganas out!
@BATTLE
The sea is confused today...
Do you think it could be Morgana about?
Could be! I'd rather flip a coin to see whether or not we'd be in immediate danger; do you have any shillings on you, Kapitan?
Do I look like I make a large pension, Orzel?
Why, with a sense of humor like that I don't see why you wouldn't make more.
Good afternoon, Orzel... Ah! This must be the Kapitan, right?
Correct! Kapitan, this is... Well, Krystian, you're better at introductions, you go ahead.
Thank you, Orzel. Pleased to meet you, Kapitan. Komandor Podporucznik Krystian Drążek at your immediate service.

Fields.MenuText: What a title!
On a first name basis with Orzel, huh?
(*Shake his hand firmly.*)

Fields.DialogueText: It may seem like a mouthful in our tongue, Kapitan, but I assure you, it basically means "Commander Lieutenant." Don't let that title fool you; Krystian is just as good natured as everyone here.

I gave everyone the option to call me by my name if they wanted, I'll have you know. Andrzej and about ten others call me "Miss Orzel." Krystian chose not to. Besides, I... don't think I really look like a "Miss", do I?

Now -that's- a handshake if I've ever seen one. I think Krystian looks more surprised than I do! Fuhaha... I can tell you two are going to get along just fine - don't let Krystian's roughness fool you!
Orzel is right, I'm not -that- gruff! I'm rather curious, Kapitan. Do you... know about these Morganas a lot? We are rather green when it comes to them.
I wish I had a good answer. There isn't a clear hierarchy, and you can't reason with them - at least not as a group. If they have any goals beyond theft and mass murder they haven't made them clear.
No wonder I feel so hot when I see one! Ah, but, between you and me, Kapitan, I believe there's something more to them.
An enemy that cannot be reasoned with... From what we've encountered, I believe that it's not that they can't be reasoned with, but that they have something else going on under the surface.
I've thought a similar thing. However, we won't know until we figure out more of it.
Seems like the luck of the draw. Hm... I should plan out a meeting with one. Do you think they'd appreciate it if we brought snacks?
Considering our encounter yester-
(*ALARM*)
Well, that settles that...
How fickle they are! Well, I suppose they wouldn't mind some... diplomacy, would they?
@BATTLE
This early in the morning? Those Morgana sure are rowdy.
(*Clap!* *Clap!*) All hands! All hands! We've got to treat our most gracious guest with some exception!
All systems stabilized! Currently taking damage from Morgana fire!
From what I can gather from radar, there's a semi-large group of them. With our current firepower... we should be able to take about three out before needing to take inventory.
Sounds good to me. What do you think, Kapitan?
I'd rather ask the ship herself first. You all right with taking care of this.
Fuhahaha! How kind of you, Kapitan, but, I trust my crew. We're all ready, just give the word, and we'll engage.
All right then, let's take them out!
@BATTLE
Excellent work!
"Teamwork"! Well done all, well done! (*Clap!* *Clap!*) How fares everything, you two?
Everything below is reading normal. I'm surprised we didn't take more damage from how aggressive those Morgana were being.
A little warning shot serves to scatter them. Really, they're like those foot soldiers of the Soviets; you fire one shot into the air and they all scatter like chickens.
That sounds like a problem for the man with the stache... I'm glad we're all on the same side when fighting with Belles.
It reminds me of how I managed to get out of Poland alive... Ah, the tangled webs we weave sometimes.

Fields.MenuText: I heard about that, it was a miracle.
Sometimes you find help in the most unlikely places.
Just goes to show, good people are everywhere.

Fields.DialogueText: A miracle? Kapitan, it was nothing short of brilliance. It was only a miracle because my crew... and the Kriegsmarine that I am here now. Lady Luck, I am not so sure - was I helped? Yes.
Don't I know that... I wonder, perhaps I could send them a gift one day? Ah, but... I still don't know how to feel about the Kriegsmarine sailors who helped me on my way after our run-in that Dismay.
My crew, and... those few in the Kriegsmarine. I wish I knew how to thank them. For now, though, I will keep going; I believe if I fight with the Belles, I fight for all.
You're quite sentimental when you want to be, you know?
That's part of my charm, Kapitan. Oh, that reminds me; would you like a cup of tea? Iwo makes a good one.
Who's Iwo? I don't believe we've met.
I'll have to introduce you when he's not sleeping. Fuhahaha!
Friend? Foe? All I know is that they're different than those Nazis who invaded...
Let's see... Paperwork regarding ammunition, crew status, letter status...
Knee deep in the paper, are you, Kapitan?
Didn't think this Captain would be a bookworm.
Good morning, Orzel, it's good to see you in high spirits. I'm guessing this is our helmsman?
That'd be me. You can call me Iwo - or "Izzy" if you'd rather. So you're our Kapitan, huh? You don't look like one.
The question is, do I look like a ship to you, Iwo?
Now you know that's a loaded question, ma'am.

Fields.MenuText: I'd say you look wonderful, Orzel.
An expert nagivator if I've ever seen one.
(Remain silent.)

Fields.DialogueText: Why... such a flatterer you are Kapitan. See, Iwo? You have your Kapitan right here; a regular songbird and a bookworm. The Kapitan is the farthest thing from ordinary!
Darn... And I thought I had him that time. Leave it to the helmsman to know when there's rough seas ahead. You see, Iwo? The Kapitan's got a sense of humor!
Pfft... Fuhahahahaha! Oh, you two! Hahahahaha! O-Oh! My sto~ho~mach!! Oh... Oh... How's about that, Iwo? The Kapitan knows what's good.
First time appearances can make a lot, but I'll see if the Kapitan can back it up. Good to meet you, anyhow.
Likewise, Iwo. Oh, Orzel. Would you mind helping me out with something?
What, Kapitan? I'll try to see if I can do anything to the best of my ability.
There's this parcel, and- Oh, hold on...
That's the telegraph! Let me see if I can translate... Ah. "CAPTAIN AND ORZEL. MISSION BRIEFING INCOMING. ROYAL NAVY CODE 1-5-8-7." Oh, that's us!
Let me see here... "MORGANA FLEET. SPOTTED NEAR FREDERIKSHAVEN DENMARK. DISPERSE THE FLEET. QUEEN AND COUNTRY. 1587 OUT."
Well, how about that! Our first mission together, Kapitan. A Morgana Fleet, hm? And Denmark, no less! I wonder if we can win some of the Danes over with this...
Either way, we should help them out. We can't have those Morganas wreaking havoc.
I feel like ruffling some feathers anyhow, so I'm with you, Kapitan! Oh, Iwo? Could you get us going on course-
Going to have to get back to the helm anyway. Do you hear that telegraph?
W-What? It started back up by itself... "S-U-R-R-E-N-D-E-R." ... Pfah! As -if-.
No ID tag... Sounds like we've got ourselves some Morgana. Would you like to reply, Orzel?
Of course, Kapitan. "BROADSIDE."
@BATTLE
Mmf... (*Munch*, *Munch*, *Munch...*) I've never had pierogi like this before.
Wonderful, aren't they? I've always found them like miniature treasure chests in every bite. Sometimes you get more meat, sometimes you get more sauce... It's a surprise in food form.
Mostly -good- surprises, I'm hoping. Hope we don't have any nasty ones before we reach Denmark. And, well, at least you can get into a Pierogi without a fuss...
Eh? "Get into?" What do you mean, Kapitan? There's nothing holding you back from taking a bite; unless, of course, you don't want these grzyb ones.
Oh, no, Orzel. It's nothing too big.
Oliwa sprawiedliwa zawsze na wierzch wypływa. It's not good to hide secrets, Kapitan. What's on your mind? You may tell me if you wish.
Well. I was sent a lockbox the other day containing a replacement for my flashlight's bulb. However... they forgot to give me the key.
Of all things to forget! Fuhaha! Do you have it on hand with you, Kapitan, by any chance?
Actually, I do, why?
Would you let me see it? I'll only take a moment with it.
Of course... Here you are.
Thank you! Hmhmhm~ (*Fwap!*) And this little button here... (*Click!* *Kerchack, kerchack, kerchack...*) Oh. This one's a tough little cookie.
Sadly, I know exactly... (*CLICK!*) where you are! And, there you go, Kapitan!

Fields.MenuText: Did you just use a feather to unlock that?
... What just happened?
I didn't think you were a magician, Orzel.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I had them designed to look like feathers. There's a particular bird, a mockingbird; think of what this is like a mockingbird, but one that mimics appearances instead of call.
Blink and you'll miss it, Kapitan. All in a days work! When in doubt, use unlikely tools to get the job done. When you don't have something fancy like this, you can just use a hairpin.
Magician? Fu... Hehehehe! Stop that, Kapitan, you'll make me blush! What I did wasn't anything more than a little bit of knowhow. The real magic comes from out at sea - this is just a tool.
Wait... That's a lockpick! Since when do you have lockpicks?!
Do you like? I had them styled like eagle feathers. I decided on getting them after we... actually had the same problem you were having! They kept forgetting to send keys!
I feel like that would be a worthy complaint to lodge with the British, wouldn't it?
Well, they lost our keys in the mail. I wonder how they’ll find our complaint?
Well... Woah! What was that!?
Ah! Iwo swerved suddenly. It would seem we have some company... Come along, Kapitan. I'll show you that my feathers aren't just for tricks!
@BATTLE
Shouldn't be that much longer to Denmark...
No, I don't think so. Krystian, do you have any estimates?
Based upon our last coordinates recorded yesterday and the time now, I believe we should be about 200 nautical miles from Esbjerg.
Sounds good. Shouldn't be more than six hours or so at our current speed. We should make it before sunset!
I hope we do. Sunsets have always been so captivating... I cannot help but wonder what Denmark's looks like.

Fields.MenuText: Well, there's a chance you could see the aurora borealis.
Snowy.
With the mountains? Excellent.

Fields.DialogueText: An aurora!? My, my! I never thought I'd behold one in my life. Getting there seems more of a treat now than simply just conducting a mission! A magical curtain like that... Oho! I'm giddy now!
Oh... I should have asked the Royal Navy to send a camera! That sounds like a once in a lifetime shot. Even if it ends up snowing, I could still take such a wonderful memory...
Oho! Goodness... Don't go riling me up this early, Kapitan. I may just push myself past speed just so I can get there sooner! Such a sight like that, it'd set my heart ablaze!
I hear Randers is a really good spot.
I hope it has a port, otherwise, we may just have to settle for Cophenhagen! Though, I wouldn't mind...
Orzel? Your eyes are wide, is everything all right?
Kapitan... I can feel them. There are so many, and they're all around us.
What? Who is? The Morg-
Kapitan! Orzel is right! Multiple hostiles detected on radar, sixteen, eighteen, twenty... No! They keep adding!
What!? Iwo! Status report, immediately!
... Ah. Aw! Son of a -bitch!- I just checked the periscope, they're everywhere! We're gonna get boxed in!
Evasive maneuvers! Get us out!
Time for a little bit of drifting..!
We've been spotted. We'll have to make our way through some of them to proceed. This... must be the fleet.
Engines are up and ready! Proceed with caution!
Let's get out of here! Orzel, with me!
Read my mind, Kapitan. Time to make an exit...
@BATTLE
Managed to get out... How many of them are there!?
This energy is too intense for me to tell... but, I feel as if they could be somewhere within the forties at least. Krystian?
I'd agree with Orzel. I counted at least twenty-two when we were boxed in. Now the number is closer to... upper thirties!
I believe the Royal Navy may have undersold how -large- this fleet was.

Fields.MenuText: First they forget the keys, and now this?
Undersold? They didn't even take stock!
How did it get -this- bad?

Fields.DialogueText: The Royal Navy seems to have larger things to worry about, and while I don't blame them - this seems perhaps a tad bit much for one submarine. Maybe we misheard the telegraph?
Pfft... Fuhahahaha! That's a -good- one, Kapitan. Do you mind if I use that later? I agree, however, that this is a bit ridiculous. A fleet this big will require at least two battleships!
I have my theories... Still, this is utterly absurd. When we have a chance, I'd send a distress signal to Denmark immediately - this is beyond anything that we can handle currently!
This was a gross underestimate of a much larger problem. The fact we even managed to break through was incredible.
There you are! "We" indeed. We all made it out of that together. Your quick actions, Krystian's estimates, Iwo's driving, and Andrzej's maintenance! Now all we have to do is make it to Denmark...
And that presents a new problem; we can't shake this fleet at all!
Indeed! They're persistent, I'll give them that!
Listen, if you two would like to take maybe two or three of these kurwa out, I can actually get us into a good current ahead!
Colorful as always, Izzy. What say you, Kapitan? I can get the engines humming a major with the right stuff if we get into that current!
It's our best shot... Prepare for combat!
With any luck, I'll have these Morgana seeing double by the time we manage to break away from them.
They'll be chasing their own ships is my hope. All right! Let's break through!
@BATTLE
I can't believe there's still stragglers! We haven't stopped battling for nearly two hours...
If we get rid of this one, we should be able to slip further away. I think we've broken away from the main fleet.
Orzel is correct, Kapitan. We've put a great distance between ourselves and their forces. At their speeds I observed, we should outpace them if we take care of this obstacle.
Suppose it's better than just leaving a fly buzzing at your ear.
Please do not remind me... A mouse got stuck in one of the engine room pipes and Andrzej had to spend a better part of an afternoon getting it out. Those squeaks are loud...
I wanted to keep him...
It's for the best you didn't. Who knows where it would've gotten?

Fields.MenuText: I don't think I'd like to think about that.
Afraid of mice, Orzel?
Wonder what else you've got hiding around here...

Fields.DialogueText: Neither would I. I'd much rather be in the company of sharks than to deal with things crawling around in my insides. I remember I had sludge in my pipes once, I wasn't right for a week!
Mice remind me of myself, Kapitan. With enough thinking, they can squeeze their way through the tightest space and wade through quagmires. I, however, value my space.
Nothing that you need to worry about, Kapitan. The most I'll keep from you is my preferences in literature. Other than that, I don't have much to hide - but I value not having my privacy invaded.
Personal space indeed. These Morganas don't seem to realize that, either.
We can't seem to shake or get rid of them, either. Krystian, how close are we to Denmark!?
Currently estimating... All right, we're about 65 nautical miles from Esbjerg.
Esbjerg! That's -way- too small of a place! And what if they follow us to the town!? That's like putting a target on everyone's heads!
It's our only good destination, Iwo! If we were to continue onward like this, we'd risk Orzel!
Bull -shit- it is! There has to be some other place we can use!
Are you doubting me, Iwo!? What about Orzel!?
What about her!? I think she wouldn't want to get civillians up in-
Boys. If you'd please. That's quite enough.
Now. Krystian and Iwo both have good points. There is, however, a middle ground. We need to lose the Morgana, yes, but we also need to find a place they won't follow us to.
Actually... There is a spot not too far from Esbjerg we can go to that we could probably lose them in. It's down a canal-
I know what you're talking about, Kapitan! That's Thyboron! The Thyboron Kanal!
Okay. Set a course for there, immediately!
Very good, Kapitan! Let's just clear a path first!
@BATTLE
Something like ten meters deep. I wouldn't want to try it submerged, but-
You've never seen me work my full magic. Just give me the order.
All right, that should do for inventory...
I am quite pleasantly surprised we kept everything intact. I didn't think they'd chase us past that little opening in Thyboron...
You made a good call in suggesting we come to Aalborg. The Kriegsmarine have been relatively civil about it, and it makes a nice base of operations.
Regardless of that, we still have a mission.

Fields.MenuText: I'm surprised you're still focused after all of that.
It looks quite grim.
That we do...

Fields.DialogueText: It's our orders. Furthermore, you cannot allow yourself to give up at the first sign of resistance. We may have come close to something terrible, but we can't let that stop us!
Somehow, I feel as though I have already braved worse odds. Think, Kapitan, We may be down, but we are by no means out! We are, however, outnumbered... But it hasn't stopped us before!
You look winded, Kapitan. I'll have to come with you into town to get some cider and perk you right up! We mustn't lose hope; we've already come this far, we need to find a way to combat the fleet.
I wasn't saying I was giving up, but it is difficult.
That -is- true. Though, we cannot simply sit here and dawdle. I think we should concoct a plan! Do we know where the fleet is?
I'm with you on the plan. The fleet? According to the intel we've gathered from the Danish, they've been spotted off the coast of Hanstholm.
Hm... Looking at the map, that doesn't seem to be that much farther than where we landed. I wonder how long it will take them to get to Copenhagen?
Krystian would probably know. But, he's gone to get some supplies. I need a minute to sit down myself...
Hehe! I agree. We should take things slow for now. I don't think that fleet will be exactly hurtling towards Cophenhagen.
Who knows? They may run into trouble at Oslo before they even get to Denmark again.
I heard about that... Wasn't that something to do with Gnevny?
I don't believe she likes to talk about it, either. Either way, Sweden and the Belle initiative aren't exactly on the best terms because of it.
Fuhahahaha! Now I -have- to hear that story for myself. It sounds like a mighty good piece of fun.
Just don't let Gnevny hear you say that.
You don't go up to somone and prick their fingers! I will, however, take the lessons she learned from that and use it for good! Now... Kapitan, would you like to play cards?
Sure. Are we playing war again?
Yes, we- Oh. I think we may have to play "war" right now. Some Morgana are...
Good spotting! I'll rassle up what crew we have. We have to protect Aalborg!
Right away!
@BATTLE
I still don't want to stay in one place too long. And maybe we shouldn't count on the Kriegsmarine staying "relatively civil."
You think they won't?
It might be worse for them if they do...
Let's see...
What have you got there, Kapitan? My, my, it's rather foggy out today.
Oh, good morning, Orzel. I decided to get a handle on the local news.
The local news? I've often wondered how it varies from country to country. In Poland, from what I've heard the boys talk about, it was rather opinionated.
It can depend on company and what city or state you're getting it in.
That sounds needlessly complicated, but it also allows you to gain viewpoints. A valuable piece indeed...

Fields.MenuText: Well, not -all- of it is valuable.
Satire's valuable as well.
Opinions, politics, gardening...

Fields.DialogueText: Those classified adds always struck me as just as tad bit too suspect. I think the price of admission is worth the pain, however. You'll never know exactly what you find!

And those comics! I have read British, American, and Polish so far. I think that the Americans have a bit of a more obvious style, and the British focus on satire a bit too much... Still! Amazing, no?
I didn't think you'd be the florist type, Kapitan. I myself was thinking about planting roses when Poland is freed... And, such stories of resolve already that I've been reading; isn't it great?
Orzel... I think I have a question for you now.
Hoh? Go ahead and ask, there isn't much I have to hide.
I've heard about your escape to Scotland. I know sailors from the Kriegsmarine helped patch you up after you ran into the Morganas - and then they let you go. How do you... feel about them now?
Fuhaha! A question like that out of the gate! I admire your bravery, Kapitan. To tell you the truth... I don't know exactly how to put it. I am grateful for them saving me, but... Poland...
Yeah. I don't really think you should.
Thank you, Kapitan. Really, though. I view the Kriegsmarine as valorous... but the cause they are fighting for is-
..! Orzel, do you see that?
Yes, I do, Kapitan! They're coming out of the fog! But they aren't attacking? Why? Can they not see us?
We might have the chance to go for a surprise attack...
Why can't they see us through this fog? Perhaps it depends on the Morgana? At this distance, we can see exactly where they're going... Wait! Wait, wait, wait, wait - that's it!
What's "it", Orzel?
Tak! They're it! Fire torpedos!
@BATTLE
The officers most responsible for helping me... you know the Germans had them charged with treason and killed, yes?
Yeah.
So even the good ones in the Kriegsmarine are bound to Hitler and his cronies, one way or another.
And it was the Kriegsmarine that fired the first shots on Poland, back in September.
Oh, I haven't forgotten.
All right... So, Orzel, what have you come up with?
Well, to be specific, Kapitan, it's what we've come up with.
I managed to analyze the weather conditions and the conditions of the channel from the Danish government.
I'm still ironing out the details... I'm rather skeptical about this.
I trust the ma'am, so...
All right, Orzel, what have you got?
Kapitan, are you sure you'd like to hear my idea? You are the Kapitan, after all - your decision means much to me, too.

Fields.MenuText: It was your level head that got us out of that mess.
I trust you, Orzel.
When an eagle perches, I sit and listen.

Fields.DialogueText: I was part of the solution, Kapitan, but it was all of us who did it together. I want everyone together again so that we can sort out this mess and hit those ghosts where it really hurts!
Kapitan... Thank you. I promise you, your trust won't be misplaced. I intend to make good on that no matter what.
Hmhm... Fuhahahahahahahaha!! That is... rather profound! Ahem! You'll make me turn scarlet, Kapitan. I'll be using that one. Now, please listen to this eagle!
All right, Orzel. Lay it on me, what should we do about the fleet?
You see, Kapitan; Andrzej has been following the local military radio reports on the secure channel relating to the navy. There have been several calls of "ghost ships" and "Draugr" in the area.

Past Aalborg is another canal that leads into the Kattegat. You see, we have the advantage here in Kattegat. Thanks to Iwo's knowledge of the terrain and weather here, we've found a certain spot. Iwo?
There are two islands, Kapitan. One is Læsø, the other is Anholt. Both of these islands during this time of year are subject to heavy fog and rough conditions for ships...
But perfect for a submarine like myself. There are also grottos around that I can fit into as well! Making it perfect for escaping. Simply put, Kapitan, we will observe them...
I get it... We can also lead them directly into Denmark's artillery!
It will be a temporary way to thin the herd, but we need something decisive. We were thinking about observing the straights to see if we could use anything.
That sounds best...
Well, Kapitan? What do you think?
It's our next best chance. Let's observe Kattegat for anything we can use and keep trying a guerilla approach for these Morganas.
I think we can start right about now...
Should have figured! All right. We'll go with this plan, come on everyone! We've got a mission to clear!
@BATTLE
Hmm...
Goodness, they're huge! I didn't think we were that outmatched...

Fields.MenuText: It's not like you to balk at the odds, Orzel!
It's like an army...
Are you all right, Orzel?

Fields.DialogueText: Fuhahahahaha! That much you know is true, Kapitan. I will admit, I do know when to look at something dangerous and concede when I may be a little out of depth - but this, I see potential in this.
An army has soul, Kapitan. There are people within me, each of different credence, background, and age; these people make up a crew and our lifeblood. What's out there is nothing but toy soldiers...
Ahaha! Ehem! K-Kapitan... Hm! I am quite fine. I'm rather exuberant, in fact. The fact that we can see them from such an advantage and... Hm... Forgive me, I have lost my train of thought.
So what you see across the sea is nothing but another obstacle?
It is an obstacle that I cannot approach yet, but that I can see how to sabotage if I look at it for long enough.
Orzel - and you don't have to answer this if it makes you feel any discomfort - but do you look at the war the same way?
You are the magistrate of difficult questions, Kapitan! But, I happen to be someone who can answer: In short, I believe this war is complex. I... still have mixed feelings about a lot of it.
Mixed feelings on what, exactly?
Well... You look at the people in Denmark, Kapitan. You see them, but around us, there are Swedish, German, Finnish, and Polish... Everyone with their own wills and pride. Everyone has their reason.
I've talked with all of the people I've said; everyone out here, everyone in their countries truly believes differently. And, some of them are so similar that it's hard to distinguish.
So who can you trust? It's a question I ask myself as well, even though I'm also fighting for my own cause.
Fuhahahaha! I trust -you-, first of all. I trust you and my crew; even if who I am fighting under may be different, I at least know that you and my crew fight with me.
Orzel...

Please, Kapitan, don't you go giving me that look! I know that you, Andrzej, Krystian, and Iwo are all with me. And I'll do what it takes to see our missions through - to make sure we all get back ok.
I promise you, Orzel. I'll do the same. I wouldn't be a Kapitan if I didn't.
Now that's the spirit!
I don't know how you do it, Orzel, but now -I'm- the one who's in higher spirits... Hm, speaking of spirits...
It appears that some Morgana are breaking off from the fleet... I think we should perhaps try to thin their numbers a bit; what do you say, Kapitan?
I say it's high time we got some payback for these Morganas always sneaking up on us. It's hide-and-seek, but this time, we're it.
@BATTLE
They haven't moved at all in the last few days... They've mostly just sent scouts out.
According to Iwo, they're mostly trying to threaten Sweden. From what Krystian has picked up from transmissions, however, the Swedes are giving them hell.

Fields.MenuText: It's not like the Morganas in the Baltic confined themselves to assaults on the Gulf of Finland. The Swedes have had practice.
Gnevny's conduct must have really upset them.
I wish we could do more for them.

Fields.DialogueText: I've heard tale from the Danes that the Swedes know how to put up a fierce firefight. From what I've heard, it sounds like rain of fire with a sea serpent in the middle...
I've heard through Krystian's monitoring of their transmissions that they still mention her name sometimes. From the vitriol Krystian said it with, it sounds like they're out for blood in the water.
I think they are quite capable by themselves, Kapitan. I've seen some Morganas come back from the Swedes, and they don't look good. But it's only a matter of time before the fleet expands...
There really aren't many places in the world where the Morganas have been more of a toxic presence than Scandinavia - the Swedes getting hit in the Baltic, the Norwegians in the North Sea.
Let's just say the whole world at large is taking exception to the Morganas and leave it at that.
Agreed. Hopefully, we can take some of the weight off of our local friends' backs.
I'm rather curious about what sort of rallying the Morgana use. Could it be they communicate with some sort of code? Or, is it more... soul-to-soul? Andrzej believes there's a chemical involved.

I've been thinking about that. It could be noise, too; whenever they're around, we hear these unsettling noises inside. Laughter, moaning, chittering, deep breathing, and whinnying... It's like anxiety.
Anxiety... Hm. I wonder, perhaps their language is what noise unsettles us the most? All of those sound different.
You know... perhaps they do? I wouldn't know. There's so many ways to speak, dialects, languages,  diphthongs - there's probably a whole method to it.
Would you like to hear a Polish tongue-twister, Kapitan?
Shoot.
Ahem. Król Karol kupił królowej Karolinie korale koloru koralowego.

Fields.MenuText: ... What? Did you just summon something?

Fields.DialogueText: Fuhahahahahahahaha!! That's the most outlandish reaction I think I've ever received to that! Oho, the look on your face..!
I could... barely register it. What does it mean?
"King Karol bought a coral coloured necklace for queen Karoline." It's a very old one.
I'll have to memorize it! Huh... Is it me, or is that Morgana rising out of the water?
Huh... I guess I -did- summon something!
@BATTLE
I'm not surprised they're all enthusiastic about punching back.
Not to make it all about Poland, but at least the Morganas haven't been poisoning the weather fifty kilometers out from Stockholm. Their experiments off the Hel Peninsula...
Fair point.

Fields.MenuText: Król Karol kupił królowej Karolinie korale koloru koralowego.

Fields.DialogueText: Very good!
"King Karol bought a coral colored necklace for queen Karoline." I knew that one.
... I wonder if that Morgana rising out of the water could pull it off.
Apparently, there's a chance that we can get a sofa in here.
Wha~t? That sounds lovely.
Wouldn't be very befitting of soldiers, though.
You would think so. However, I believe that it would show off our confidence in ourselves; what soldier would roll into battle on a sofa except one who was sure of their resolve?
A maniac, probably-
Kapitan! Ma'am!
Iwo? What's going on? Are there Morgana about?
No, no! We've got an even bigger company - it's the Kriegsmarine. I've picked them up on radar, and Krystian says he's heard radio transmissions of from Odense; there's a fleet there!
The North Sea group? They're supposed to be intercepting Morganas off the Norwegian coast, aren't they? What are they doing here?

Fields.MenuText: Sightseeing?
As long as it's not another Heligoland experiment...
I think I'm more confused than you are, Orzel.

Fields.DialogueText: Sightseeing at a time like this! I admire their appreciation for the finer countryside of Denmark, but this isn't the time for that. What could they be doing? Military operations? Training?
No signs of it so far. I wonder what they're doing?
Confusion can lead to understanding later, Kapitan. One must treat such situations with the eyes of someone who's looking from a bigger perspective. Still, why is the Kriegsmarine present..?
Did Krystian happen to pick up any transmissions that might tell us what they're up to, Iwo?
Actually, there were a few. We can't get heads or tails why they're really there, but so far, the only thing we've consistently heard is "diplomacy."
Are there any German Belles among them?
None that we've heard of. But, they are on high alert because of the Morganas.
High alert... Morgana... Na Boga... That's it!
Got a plan, Ma'am?
Absolutely, but I'll need the Kapitan's help as well.
I'm all ears, Orzel. Your plan and everyone's efforts got us into Aalborg and out of the fleet's crosshairs.
Yes! There you are, Kapitan! As a team, we can fly as high as an eagle!
Gah! Co jest grane? I just felt the rudder shudder...
Oh, that's right... Kapitan, I-
Morganas around, right? Let's surprise them. Iwo, Orzel, with me.
@BATTLE
Now entering Samso's waters!
Well, well, well... Let's see what we're working with here.
Steady as she goes, Iwo - and keep your eyes open for potential complications. According to our intelligence, the Kriegsmarine have been active here for the past few days.
... We're not the only ones here, it seems. I sense them.
Make haste for battle. We have to take those Morganas out, or else there's a chance the Kriegsmarine would be alerted to our presence.
@BATTLE
I think that should be it... How close are we now?
I'm picking up transmissions from the Kriegsmarine. They don't seem any wiser to us being here, and from our vantage point of nearly 20 nautical miles, we should be able to see them...
Oh... boy. I sure as hell do. Are you seeing this, ma'am, Kapitan?
What is this? Why are there so many ships? That has to be at least thirty...

Fields.MenuText: All of those destroyers, too...
A "diplomatic mission", huh?
They're certainly making themselves at home in Danish waters.

Fields.DialogueText: Destroyers, light cruisers... If I didn't know the Kriegsmarine likes to come prepared, I would say they're compensating for something. This, however, leads me to our next step...
Some real "gunboat diplomacy" we have present. Either the Kriegsmarine knows of the fleet, or has been hearing of increased Morgana activity. Either way, this is proving better than expected.
It's advantageous, anyhow...
You seem rather confident, Orzel. Is this... part of your plan?
It most certainly is. And now that we know exactly how much firepower the Kriegsmarine has, these straights are going to become a graveyard for the Morganas.
... I think I see where you're going with this.
Have you, Kapitan? Well, then would you like to tell me what I intend?
We're going to lure the Morgana towards Odense and hope our German friends will still be around.
Actually, they should be here for the next two weeks according to their transmissions. That gives us plenty of time.
Well then... Let's put this plan into action. What's our first step, Orzel?
The first step? We have to head back towards those islands and draw the fleet's attention. It'll be risky, but we have to get them to follow us. We'll get some more details as we go; are you with me?
When the eagle is perched, I'll listen with all I have. Let's go together!
We're getting reinforcements? I was under the impression that-
I'm the submarine that got away, as far as the men in Berlin are concerned. If I appeal to the Kriegsmarine for help, even under the League flag, I don't know what their orders would be.
But I know what would happen to Kriegsmarine officers who ignored their orders and helped anyway.
No, much better that we're not a part of their thinking at all!
The mist is still way too strong out here...
We'll be needing that, Kapitan. Do you see any of the fleet yet?
Nope. I'm beginning to wonder if this spyglass I have is an outdated model.
I ought to get you a new one after this mess is over with. If there's one thing I cannot stand, it's broken tools. Both I and Andrzej are firmly against having bad tools to use.

Fields.MenuText: And here I thought you would find use in everything...
Shouldn't you fix your tools?
It's like keeping on your toes, no?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, believe me, I do, Kapitan. However, someone who values themselves should always keep good equipment on them. What happens when a soldier's rifle should jam from lack of upkeep?
Absolutely. If it is possible to fix them, you should. What I am saying, however, is that you shouldn't use things that are broken. Value yourself, value your possessions!
You get me, Kapitan. That's exactly right; you should be ready for anything. Always assume that things will go awry. You will never know the outcome, but you will feel comfortable with yourself.
Having good tools and keeping yourself sharp, that I agree with. I don't think, however, that because something might be old, doesn't mean it no longer has value.
Hmhm! Good point, Kapitan. I've heard Iwo say it before, but "if it isn't broke, don't try fixing it." I agree with that sentiment as well. Oh, can you see anything now?
Unfortunately not. I'm going to have to send for a new one - or maybe Andrzej can fix it?
Oh! I have no doubt he'd be able to, Kapitan. He may not look like it, but Andrzej knows his way around a lot of things.
He's been rather quiet this trip. I hope I haven't done anything to-
No, no, not at all, Kapitan. Andrzej isn't offended, he's just one of those people that only speaks when he feels the need to. Although, I enjoy talking to him when he's off duty.
I ought to reach out to him. I've gotten to know Iwo and Krystian so much. And, of course, you too, Orzel.
I've enjoyed getting to know you, too, Kapitan. It's as if you've been a member of my crew all of this time, but only made yourself known now!
Hearing you say that makes me feel warm. Thank you, Orzel. I'll keep doing my best.
As will I, Kapitan. We've made it this far together, and now... we need to be brave.
Ah, that tone of voice... You sense Morganas about?
Absolutely. Kapitan... check towards port with your spyglass; I believe that's where they are.
Let's see... On the money, Orzel. And that's not only a large contingent, I think those Morgana are some of the main fleet.
All right, Kapitan. It's time. We get in, we hit them with a few salvo, and then we make them follow us back to Odense.
When the cat's away, the mice will play.
Please do not remind me of mice again, Kapitan... Ah, forget it. Let's go!
@BATTLE
Now we've got them upset...
If we have them upset now, they won't like the next part I had planned: Andrzej!
Yes, Miss Orzel!
It's time for the "Kaleidoscopes." Load them up, if you'd be so kind!
Right away!
"Kaleidoscopes?"
You might love this, Kapitan. Are you ready?
Of course I am. Engage this contingent; give them hell!
@BATTLE
Excuse me... Maybe I saw it weirdly, but are there lights in the water? It's like looking at the night sky out there...
That'd be my work, Kapitan. These are the "Kaledioscopes." They're meant to draw attention.
That's... Andrzej, how? I may need a full report on that later.
I was so surprised when I saw the clusters myself in practice. I still can't get over how pretty they look...

Fields.MenuText: That smile of yours is glowing!
Let's see them wrap their heads around that!
It took a lot of courage to trust in that...

Fields.DialogueText: Ahaha! Kapitan! Always with the flattery! Though, I can't help but beam brightly. Seeing it work in action is truly something else, and having seen your reaction and pride - all worth!
Didn't you see how they slid and maneuvered around? If they didn't know where we were before, they know now! But, seeing them get that spooked at a little noise; that was priceless!
It did, but, I have faith in Andrzej as much as everyone else here. I trust you, Kapitan, and to feel your trust in me, to know you appreciate my courage - it's wonderful.
I will admit, this does feel like we've gotten them good. My cheeks hurt.
Fuhahahaha! You look cute with your cheeks flushed like that. Now, now... Time for the next part of the plan.
They're coming in our direction... Right! Back to Odense! Full speed! Ah, but, how are we going to get the Kriegsmarine?
I'll need your help for that, actually, Kapitan.
What?
Oh, you'll see...
Simply put, they're these little clusters of engineered fireworks that detach from the torpedoes shortly after launch.
So far so good...
We're almost there... Now, we need to get rid of these last few Morgana and fire off some more "Kaleidoscopes" and we'll be good!
Sounds good to me! Engage!
@BATTLE
Good, we're keeping great pace now. How are we looking, Krystian?
The Morgana are behind us and are steadily giving chase. Those last ones we destroyed should be the last; I'm not detecting any others on radar.
Excellent. Now for the long distance murder dash...
Plenty of time for you to test your acting chops, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: My what?
I can't act, Orzel.
I can act, but I'm not a thespian.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh come now, Kapitan. Surely you know how to make your voice different? Picture this: you're embodying a commanding officer who you clashed with in the past - how did they sound to you?
You can't act, yet you're a Kapitan? Fuhahahaha! Don't worry too much, I'll help you figure out how. It's all in your body language and position of your chest, Kapitan. I'll be right beside you.
That's quite all right. We don't need a thespian, we need someone who can imitate. If you wanted to become a thespian, I wouldn't mind helping you in that endeavor. After all, acting is much fun!
Oh... Wait, I feel like I've put it together. You want me to speak to the Kriegsmarine, don't you?
Well, you won't be "speaking" like yourself per se.
Tell me about the smoke and mirrors, Orzel.
Fuhahaha!!! Now you're on my wavelength, Kapitan. The plan is to have you imitate a Morgana's speech patterns. You don't have to change your voice too much, you simply have to imitate a Morgana.
And you think the Kriegsmarine will buy that I'm a Morgana and not a Kapitan? Can't they read our transmission?
You can leave the hiding transmission part to me. As for how you'll sound... Andrzej will be the one to take care of that.
Normally, I'd be fearful, but so far we've been doing well. What's one more trick?
That's the spirit. Now all we have to do is get to the Odense!
I second that. Full-speed ahead!
Entering Odense waters!
Kriegsmarine spotted on radar, at least 15 nautical miles out! Are you ready, Kapitan?
Ready as I'll ever be...
You've got this, Kapitan. Andrzej will explain how it works.
So, Kapitan. What you're going to do is speak into this microphone here... Krystian and I have created a unique sound scenario with the equipment to replicate a Morgana's tone and voice tendencies.
You actually managed to do that? ... Ah, I get it. You recorded those vocalizations earlier after Orzel heard them, didn't you?
You catch on quickly, Kapitan! We will play the recordings and pitch your delivery down. All you need to now is threaten the Kriegsmarine with something ominous.
Oh dear...
Come on, Kapitan! You can do this!

Fields.MenuText: Did... you just jump?
A-All right, all right! I can't take it when you're pumped up like that...
I'm getting a feeling that you'll enjoy this.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course I'm jumping. Can't you see how exciting this is!? We're at the last leg of the build up of our plan before we set everything into motion... And, I'm a little excited on hearing you speak.
Fuhahahaha! I'm sorry, Kapitan. I can't help it. I always get excited when things start coming together. Oh! Don't speak yet, I need to pull up a chair and really listen...
Oho... What gave it away, Kapitan? I suppose I'm not trying to hide it either. I'm curious to see how you'll be the voice to the Morgana! That, and you look so pumped yourself, I'm excited!
Well... All right, here goes nothing.
Go ahead, Kapitan! The microphone is all yours! Really strike fear into the Kriegsmarine!

Fields.MenuText: (Channel your inner Morgana for the Kriegsmarine.)

Fields.DialogueText: Oh... Oh my... How did you do that with your voice and can you please do it again?
Well if it gets you that amped up, I wouldn't mind doing it again after the mission is over... I hope that—
Good God. It's ALL German. They're yelling so much and scrambling that I can't even make heads or tails on what they're ordering! It's like listening to several of Hitler's speeches at once!
That's our cue... And, shit! I'm seeing Morgana on the radar, too, some of them followed all the way behind us!
Kriegsmarine movement detected as well: four destroyers incoming! Other ships mobilizing as well!
Time to fly like an eagle, Kapitan.
All right... For the future of Denmark, let's show these Morgana what it means to be tricked.
With pleasure!
@BATTLE
I never thought I'd find myself in a situation like this!
Dodging the salvo of the Kriegsmarine while running towards the Morganas?

Fields.MenuText: The fact you aren't yelling is...
You're awfully calm about this!
I will admit, it is kind of exhilarating.

Fields.DialogueText: There's no reason to scream, Kapitan. In situations like these, clear communication is key. If a soldier is to rally his men, he should do it with sense, no? Likewise, we must hold firm - persist!

You have to be, Kapitan. Please. Take some deep breaths and understand that we're all here with you. We are moving as one right now, we're the eagle, and we need to be brave. Take my hand if you wish!
Fuhahaha! There you are, Kapitan. Bravery is what's needed here - being calm is just an afterthought of bravery. That isn't to say everything is quite all right, but we have the courage to continue.
Orzel... All right. I trust you, and I trust the crew as well.
Then let our flag rise high and spirits rise higher!
These salvos are a bit too close for comfort. Those Germans can aim well!
You and the crew have been aiming well this entire excursion; I'd say it's high time you learnt how to dodge!
But... I'm not the one driving.
Dodge your fear, Kapitan. Embrace your courage. Look at Iwo, does he look scared?
-Not- the time, ma'am!
At least we're holding together...
Would you like some tea, Kapitan?
Wait a moment, where did you get that pot?
Andrzej just handed it to me. I had asked him to start making it earlier.
I can see you've already embraced British culture. Sure, I'll take some... (*Sip!*) Hey... this is pretty good.
Do you like it? Andrzej said he got this blend specially from Aalborg. Apparently, they make it with ginseng and acorns.
I can really feel the... "nuttiness."
Listen, I appreciate you two are remaining calm, but we have some Morgana up ahead!
Orzel?
Don't have to tell me twice!
@BATTLE
I'm surprised we were able to get clear.
That maneuver was some stroke of genius, I'll have to give it to Iwo!
Look at how fiercely the Kriegsmarine are going at it...
They're sending more and more destroyers and cruisers, but we haven't detected a single U-boat yet.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe they know we're here?
Maybe they're all raiding out further in the Atlantic.
They could be not too far behind...

Fields.DialogueText: If they did, they would've gone back, thinking that a lazy Polish submarine just baited them into doing work. No, their mission has changed, Kapitan. Now instead of diplomacy, it's search and destroy!
It's possible! Good thing the surface ships seem to be up to the task!
We knew the risks when we began, Kapitan. What's required of us now is only courage. Our fears are somewhat warranted, but I believe they're not as half terrifying as how the Morgana feel now!
I'm still surprised at how much hell they're giving those sea witches.
Well, I have heard they're thorough...
Aren't you thorough, Orzel? You accounted for pretty much everything that's happened so far.
I may be thorough, but it is my crew and Kapitan that have always set me right and act as my counsel.
True, but you, Orzel, you're a natural born leader.
K-Kapitan... Ogh... Hm! Fuha... Fuhahahahahaha! I don't know why, but I am beaming with pride when you say such things to me!
You deserve it, Orzel. Without your level-head and ardent courage, I no doubt would've had a much harder time being a Kapitan.
Orzel? Did I say something wrong?
No, no! Far from it, Kapitan. You've simply made me become caught in my own tongue. I haven't had this happen since Iwo told me an English tongue twister.
Oh, that's right. I'll see if I can't find any that may confuse you.
Fuhahaha! Cheeky as always, Kapitan. But! You should know I, and the rest of the crew, are glad to have you aboard.
As am I! Now, all we need to do is...
Hm? Ah! Kapitan, look! It appears the Morganas are finally starting to play it seriously; those are some stiff reinforcements.
What do you say we help our German friends out?
Fuhahaha! With pleasure... Get below deck! Get ready to dive and engage!
@BATTLE
All hands! All hands!
I feel like I'm flying, Kapitan! Fuhahaha! Rush on ahead!
I don't think I've seen you this excited since we first left Aalborg.
Because everything's finally coming together, Kapitan. Look at us! We're in the middle of the Morgana and the Kriegsmarine, flying at an indomitable speed!
I can barely hold onto my seat!
Don't you want to fly, too, Kapitan?

Fields.MenuText: I thought we were in the water?
Maybe after we're out of this!
With you, Orzel? Yes.

Fields.DialogueText: When you view the entire world in front of you as the sky, Kapitan, you want to exceed every limit that you're capable of. That's how we're pushing through, even now!
Fuhahaha! Once we're out of here, I ought to have you build some exercises in getting you used to how fast I can go! Besides, look at us, we're practically clawing through the Morganas!
Don't make me go all stark-mouthed now, Kapitan! Save the pleasantries for later, right now, we're soaring through! If you'll compliment anything, compliment yourself for being with me!
Well! In high spirits, and in high gear...
Wooohoooooooo~!
Ah..! Kapitan, Orzel. I'm detecting Morgana artillery units on radar!
Periscope... Damn it! Krystian's right! If we don't do something about them soon, those cruisers and destroyers are going to be in trouble!
We can use the "Kaleidoscopes" to draw their attention... but I don't think the artillery is going to fall for it...
This is a simple solution. It's risky, but...
I'm all ears, Orzel.
We've got to maneuver underneath the front line of the Morgana and sew havoc into the backlines.
That's... Yes! That's exactly what we need to do!
While I'm inclined to agree, Kapitan - how the hell am I supposed to get under them without them noticing?
Taking a page out of Orzel's planning book - how about this? We wait for the artillery to start firing high, then we use the crescendo of the salvos to sneak underneath, and then get to attacking?
Fuhahaha! Now -that's- it, Kapitan! That's perfect!
All right... I'll do my best. Krystian! You need to stay on that radar and point shit out to me; Andrzej, get those torpedoes ready! Let's move it!
Onward!
@BATTLE
Visibility's miserable! Can anybody tell me what our status is?
I can, Kapitan! Hold on! We're making good progress; if you need to, take my hand!
Loading more torpedoes! Increasing salvo output by 20%!

We've taken out some of their more fierce contenders for heavy fire - there's only a few contingents left. However, the Morgana have noticed us and are forming a blockade to try and defend the artillery!
Come on... keep it together... Come on!!! We're so close! This is like the stock car races in Wisconsin! COME ONNNN!!!
If we break through these Morgana and take out their artillery, this will bust them wide open! The fleet is finished!
Come along, Kapitan! Let's do one last act - we'll make all these Morganas...
Disappear!
@BATTLE
Gah! That was a -big- explosion, hold on!
Come on...! Yes! YES! We're through!
Position us behind the Morganas - we have to cut them off, Iwo! Krystian, make sure nobody else comes to help; Andrzej, keep those torpedoes primed!
Aye! Aye!

Fields.MenuText: Not bad, people!
I think I can feel my teeth in my skull...
(*Hug Orzel*)

Fields.DialogueText: Snrrk... Fuhahahaha! Oh, Kapitan, if you could see the look on your face! It looks like you just took a big bite out of a really good piece or Sernik! I'm... It touches me to see you like that!
W-Woah! Kapitan! Easy there! Hold on... I've got you. That's it. Take a seat... You've -more- than earned it. Good holly, you look as if you're going to pass out - but your smile is so... beautiful!
E-Eep! Aww... Ahahahaha! Kapitan, yes! Thank you, thank you so mu~ch! Haha! Goodness... You know, you hug really tight! I can really feel how happy you are... it's getting me all giddy!
You're pretty good at this, you know.
Oh, Kapitan! Thank you for being with us, and acting as our comrade in arms! You're the best-
Orzel! The Morganas are disappearing! The fleet is collapsing by numbers fast, and it doesn't look like they'll last any longer. I can see it, they're disappearing on radar!
Fuhahaha! Not so big now, are they?
Should we pick off the stragglers?
I don't think that's necessary... The Kriegsmarine isn't showing any quarter at all. The Morganas are fleeing quickly, but those destroyers should catch up quick.
Speaking of which... German communications have returned. I can make out some big ones on the central ships; mostly, they're cheering and wondering how the artillery was dealt with.
Huh! Well...
How about you give them a message yourself, Orzel? After all, I spoke last time.
Krystian, could you please turn on the voice dampener? Thank you... Ahem!
Vielen Dank für eure Hilfe, alte Freunde. Aufpassen~
Wow... That... I'm going to need a moment for that voice.
Fuhahaha! Thank you, Kapitan. Shall we get going now?
Of course, Aalborg awaits!
*BOOM*
Aalborg looks so much more peaceful now.
Anyway... yeah. Aalborg. It's nice to be able to see it without guns ringing in our ears.
It doesn't surprise me the boys have gone for drinks, either! Ah... And then they left us to receive Denmark's delegation and take inventory of our munitions and rations...
I'm happy to take care of it as long as it means they get some well deserved rest.
I wasn't expecting the Danes to greet us with such love... All these supplies, gifts, and letters of thanks.
All of those are thanks to you, Orzel. You've done admirably, more than I could ever ask a Belle to do.
And likewise to you, Kapitan. You were encouraging, patient, and willing to work with me and my crew to the best of our ability.
Seriously, you need to stop pushing back when I compliment you. You've shown some exceptional leadership qualities in this endeavor, Orzel.
Hm... You know, being here like this, I don't actually... hate taking some of the credit for my leadership. I appreciate you saying such things to me, Kapitan.
I wouldn't say such things if I didn't believe they weren't true, Orzel.
Speaking of, didn't our friends back in Britain send us something?

They did! Krystian got a transmission of thanks and a promise of a sizeable bonus from the Royal Navy. They said "without Orzel, the situation would've been chaotic, thanks to your efforts, Denmark is safe."
Ahaha! Well, all in a day's work. The merit of having gotten to see Denmark's lovely sunsets in the snow was worth its own reward in gold.
You won't believe this, but, you've also repaired the Belle Initiative's relationship with Sweden a bit thanks to your work. They were impressed with how you handled the fleet.
Oh, I forgot to ask, what about the Kriegsmarine?

I don't think they're any the wiser, or at least, I haven't heard anything regarding it. Krystian said that aside from confusion, he heard cheering and hollering; most likely, they'll be rewarded too.
I hope they got back safely. Hah... Goodness me, is it normal to be so tired after an endeavor like that?
I mean you coordinated what was essentially an entire misdirection operation, waded through fire, and then came out on top despite extraordinary odds. I'd say you've more than earned the right.
I suppose that in itself was the magic act. With a sleight of hand, you and I made those Morgana crumble.

Fields.MenuText: Smoke, mirrors, and bonds, I'd do it all again.
I'd make a bouquet appear for you, if I could.

Fields.DialogueText: Fuhahahaha! Well said, Kapitan. I'm looking forward to playing more tricks and achieving much more in the future with you.
So as long as you don't put me in a straight-jacket...
Now that... that I don't think I can promise! Fuhaha! But, I promise I will do everything I can to make sure you're safe and taken care of.
Hu... Huh? K-Kapitan? I... Erm... I didn't see any flowers about here. B-But! I appreciate that you would give me some. You don't need to make them appear! W-Where did that come from!?
I think you've been rubbing off on me, Orzel. And, I'm not ashamed to say I'd like to pick a card.
My card's not so easily drawn, Kapitan! B-But... Ah... The feeling is mutual. I look forward to our partnership, and I promise to do everything I can to take care of you.
Okay. What are you looking at so intently?
Oh, y'know... the bird made of water flying around out there.
Please tell me that's one of your magic tricks and not a new Morgana thing.
Oh! Fantom! Yes, he's mine - a little entertainment I made for the crew in... darker times. He's almost independent of me now, I suppose.
Really?
The best magic tricks are bigger than the magician, you know.
Hm.
But he'll dissolve back into the sea again soon - I can't keep him going forever. I actually know a Finnish Belle who says she could give me some pointers, but-
Come on. You've got to do it. The crew needs a magic water bird.
Do they?
Your captain says so.
Then who am I to say no?
